subject: The Horror, The Horror
event:
Well, if you like defense, you had to like the Giants / Cowboys game.  Two great defenses slugging it out, and throttling the offenses.  Unfortunately the ending sucked.

Losing to the Cowboys is always painful.

The Giants look like a ghost of themselves without Plaxico Burress and Brandon Jacobs.  It's becoming clear that the foundation of Earth, Wind, and Fire is Earth.  I do wish Coughlin had gone to Fire in the third quarter, when it became clear that Wind wasn't getting it done.  

The other Giants receivers need to step up with Plax gone, but so far they haven't.  Eli got no help at all tonight, either from his receiving corps or his offensive line.

Sigh.  And next Sunday, the Panthers come to down.

comments.article: Tonight was a disappointment. That said, I enjoyed watching T.O. fall on his ass. Classic.

I was expecting the past two losses. Strangely, I feel confident about the rest of the season.
The defense was extremely good but not perfect. Tuck looked healthier than he has in past weeks. Now they just need to adjust to the delays, draws, screens and backs getting open. If 'Boys had run some bootlegs I suspect that those would have worked too. I think they should utilize more run blitzes than the cover blitzes they've been using.
Offensively, they need to choose to make a receiver (not necessarily a wide) 'the' threat. Hedgecock has disappeared. Jacobs should be back and that will help but I believe that Boss needs to be emphasized. Bradshaw has not been healthy which has made him a relatively easy tackle and he has not shined in the opportunities he's had this season. Last week he failed to recognize what the defense was doing and adjust. His blocking is not great, he doesn't know how to find the soft spot when he goes out and he drops the ball. Plus, he's a bit in the doghouse for his indiscretion about going stripclubbing and being with Pierce and Burress. He should have known that he needed to keep his nose in the playbook and his butt at home especially after the offseason he's had. If he were a better receiver they could use him as a scat back. They were looking to Hixon to replace Plax and lets face it, he doesn't have the tools yet. And he's hurt. Seubert and McKenzie are serious issues, but even if they are unable to recover, I think that they have the parts to re-solidify the O-line. Well we'll see if they can do something positive with the offense.

So why do I feel good about next week? It's purely based on my belief that they are playing themselves out of the funks and the coaching will adjust appropriately. This is smart team. Even Plax was a smart player. I hope I'm not disappointed next week. When I get upset over the Mets and Giants losing I have trouble sleeping and end up with headaches. Pitiful.
You realize, sir, that because of you and you alone I will purposefully root AGAINST my home team in favor of your Giants, yes?

I've rooted for a friend's team from time to time, but I've NEVER turned my back on my team for anyone.

George's books are fun, but c'mon, turning on your own team?

Choke yourself.

Will
comments.subject: Rooting against the home team?

comments.article: The one bright thought in this year of being a KC Chiefs' fan:  I'm not a Detroit Lion's fan.
I keep that thought in mind as well.

Because of this Dallas win, the Falcons are knocked out of the playoff picture with only two games remaining.  We REALLY needed the Giants to take care of the Boys this week.  Ah well.  At least Dallas has two tough games remaining on their schedule.

cowboys=lannisters... they win alot.. but in the end they all get fucked... except the cool little dwarf who got his revenge in crows and from the prelude... well... I'll keep those thoughts to myself

You have no idea how badly I want the Giants to win next Sunday.

Okay, maybe you do.
Love your books and all but... Go Cowboys.

Oh NO! 2 bad NY football games. I'm thinking that means that the people North of the Wall overrun the entirety of Westeros. Starks will be flayed and whipped in the streets, and the #@$%@^%@ Lannisters will win. BOO HISS!

Then again, I'm glad that GRRM supports the Giants... Because if he supported the Dead-skins, the entire continent would be burning now... Winter or no.

I wouldn't worry too much. This was a huge desperation game for the Cowboys. If they lost their season was close to over. That being said I do think that loosing Plax is a huge deal. Having to game plan for him makes all the other receivers the Giants have better.

That being said hopefully they meet up again in the NFC Championship game. (And hopefully the Cowboys win getting a little revenge for last year.)

The Panthers rock.

Woe unto those who hold hope than any may defeat them in coming weeks.

Superbowl all the way...

I decided to watch a movie, Eragon, for most of the game, I just didn't want to see the Cowboys lose to the Giants.

The movie ends, and I eventually try to see what the damage is. 14 to 3, 9 minutes to go. I think to myself, "crap, they're going to have to step it up if they're going to win." They stopped the Giants so they're getting the ball back. The crowd seems a lot happier about the situation than... oh wow, the Cowboys are the ones with 14!

I'm still glad I didn't watch the game though, I'm not a fan of defensive struggles... they're even more boring than the movie Eragon.
comments.subject: Incredible

comments.article: I hope Christopher Paolini learned his lesson from the "Eragon" film.  Artistic license is one thing, but the film was so far off from the book that the sequels wouldn't make any sense.
comments.subject: Re: Incredible

comments.article:
Meow

(here comes the Panthers baby!!!)

I won't worry unless the Giants lose against the Panthers.  Looking beyond this season (regardless of how it ends), if the Giants mean to cut ties with Plax it's clear they need to find Eli a monster WR threat in the offseason.  The Giants have extra picks from the Shockey trade, so I'd love to see them trade up on draft day and somehow land Michael Crabtree.
Sorry, Mr. Martin, but I gotta root for my Panthers here. We will probably be CRUSHED but I still have to show some team spirit!

1:35 pm Monday and Eli just got sacked again . . . Boy, that was fun! If we hadn't GIVEN that &^%#* game to the Steelers last Sunday, the Giants would be shaking in their boots right now!

This just in: there's a D in Dallas. Our D plays like this the rest of the season, we can beat ANYbody, right on through January.

Uh...really love your work, George! Big fan of yours every day but Sunday.

Cheers,

Nick
First I am a Lions fan (I know, speaking of horror), but I live in Charlotte and I hope the Panthers can find some way of staying competitive with the Giants.  I am very afraid of the D line...
comments.subject: Gotta root for BOTH my teams...

comments.article:
Judging from the way the Panthers mauled my still skitzo Broncos, I'd say the Giants have their hands full.

Big time.

I've endured the New York comments (some fair; but it is your website)for some time now and I can't wait for Sunday.  So far no panthers have shot themselves (or their spouses), so therefore I believe the Panthers will win!
comments.subject: New York Football

comments.article:
You can't just replace a talent like Plaxico Burress. Regardless of what you say about him, he is probably one of the top receivers in the league, and was the go to guy for the Giants when they needed certain plays.

Also Jacobs is very important too.

I agree the cowboys winning is no good.

I felt the same way about an earlier game when my team got bungled.
comments.subject: Re: The Horror, The Horror

comments.article:
Yeah, we Falcons fans were really rooting for you.

Dang.

It really has to come down to the fact that the Giants need a consistent reception threat, and I for one think that Steve Smith is up to the challenge as a Anquan Boldin like receiver.  Eli just needs to look for him on downs other than 3 and we'll start seeing the chains move.  Another thing is that it would be nice to see what the rookie Manningham has in terms of talent in the bigs.  All that being said, a healthy Jacobs for the postseason makes the Giants the favorites, period.
comments.subject: Receivers

comments.article: Well first off, when these two teams squared off for the fisrt time a little over a month ago there was a lot of chatter going on in the Giants locker room leading up to the game. If you'll remember Dallas was missing Tony Romo, Felix Jones, Kyle Kosier, Roy Williams, Terrance Newman, Kevin Burnett, Miles Austin to injury. Also, Jason Witten played but was not effective due to freshly broken ribs a week previous. So that totals 5 injured starters (4 Pro-Bowlers last year) and 3 key back-ups. Star defensive end Justin Tuck was quoted as sayin that the Giants "don't feel sorry for them" and that he hoped that they wouldn't use the injuries as an excuse for losing the game. The Giants ended up throttling Dallas that game, but this week it was the reverse. So please spare me all the talk about missing Plax and Jacobs. No excuses remember, besides Dallas didn't have their feature back Marion Barber anywhere near healthy for the game eieher.
comments.subject: How about them Cowboys!!!

comments.article:
I went to kindergarten driving by Dallas Stadium, so I reluctantly admit to being a Cowboys fan.

*hides while people pelt him with rocks and garbage*

The interesting thing is this: It will be a hell of a playoff series. There are a surprising number of teams who on any given day, look all but invincible - or turn into a troop of girl scouts.

No offense to girl scouts intended or implied.

Like a good Martin novel, I like not knowing what's about to happen next.

In that sense, the Giant's loss will help make things more interesting in the coming weeks.
comments.subject: Should be an interesting playoff

comments.article: Thank God for the Rams...that's all I have to say.
